awd_titl_txt: Exploring Spin-Orbit Coupling and Correlated Phenomena in Iridate-Based Ferroelectric Transistors and Tunnel Junctions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
In heavy transition metal oxides such as iridates, the electron spin is strongly coupled with its orbital motion. This effect, when competing with other interactions involving the charge and structural order, can significantly alter the material's electronic and magnetic properties. This research project explores two material strategies to understand, control and enhance these couplings in iridate-based composite materials. The gained knowledge can be utilized to design novel nanoscale devices that transcend the performance limits of the current information technology. The research provides exciting research opportunities for students at the graduate, undergraduate and high school levels, exposing the students to cutting-edge nanoscience and materials research. The integrated outreach components aim at promoting the K-12 STEM education and disseminating science to the general public. The efforts include creating a web-based comic story centered around a teenage girl learning the related device concept and its application in modern electronic technology, and contributing a post on the related topic to the Funsize Physics website.

Technical Abstract:
The goal of this research project is to probe and control the spin-orbit coupling and correlation-driven phenomena in epitaxial thin films of the 5d transition metal oxides SrIrO3 and Sr2IrO4 using two prototype device structures, the ferroelectric field effect transistors and the ferroelectric tunnel junctions. The research activities include examining the individual roles of carrier density, lattice strain, and defects in the spin transport of SrIrO3, modulating the magnetic anisotropy in Sr2IrO4, searching for carrier density-driven metal-insulator and magnetic phase transitions, and exploring the tunneling characteristics of iridate-based tunnel junctions. This research involves advanced epitaxial deposition of complex oxide heterostructures, nanoscale device fabrication, scanning probe microscopy, variable temperature magnetotransport and tunneling spectroscopy studies. The proposed efforts stand to advance the fundamental understanding of spin-orbit coupling and its competition with various correlated energies in the heavy transition metal oxides. The gained knowledge can be leveraged to develop novel oxide-based nonvolatile or multifunctional electronic and spintronic applications.

por.por_cntn:
In this research project, 3d and 5d transition metal oxide thin films and heterostructures have been exploited as model systems to understand and control a range of emergent phenomena driven by spin-orbit coupling and correlation effect. High quality epitaxial oxide thin film samples have been fabricated into prototype capacitor devices, ferroelectric field effect transistors, and ferroelectric tunnel junctions. High precision electrical and magnetotransport measurements have been combined with structural characterization and scanning probe microscopy studies to examine the roles of charge density, lattice strain, disorder, and band intrinsic Berry phase effect in controlling phenomena such as metal-insulator transition, magnetic anisotropy, and anomalous Hall effect. Among the achievements are the observation of an abrupt enhancement of spin-orbit scattering time in ultrathin perovskite strontium iridate films close to the dimensionality-driven metal-insulator transition, the strong perpendicular magnetic anisotropy and robust anomalous Hall effect stabilized in ultrathin spinel nickel cobaltite films down to 1.5 unit cell thickness, the demonstration of ferroelectric polarization controlled metal-insulator transition in strontium iridate thin films, and up to 103 tunneling electroresistance achieved in iridate and nickelate-based ferroelectric tunnel junctions. Piezoresponse force microscopy studies have been carried out to examine the domain wall roughness in epitaxial ferroelectric oxide films deposited on various correlated oxide electrodes, which provide important materials information for realizing nanoscale control of the ferroelectric field effect. Probing the transient negative capacitance effect in ferroelectric/dielectric heterostructures also reveals the critical roles of depolarization and domain formation in modifying the ferroelectric free energy profile. Integrating ferroelectric oxide thin films and free-standing membranes with monolayer MoS2 further leads to an unconventional nonlinear light filtering effect that can be programed at the nanoscale.

The intellectual merit of this research project includes the enhanced understanding of spin-orbit coupling-controlled spin transport, correlation-driven quantum phase transitions, and strain-modulation of magnetic anisotropy in strongly correlated materials. It also facilitates the nanoscale design of novel electronic and magnetic states in transition metal oxides. The completion of this research project has resulted in the publication of fourteen peer-reviewed journal papers (2 Advanced Materials, 1 Advanced Science, 2 Physical Review Applied, 1 Physical Review Materials, 1 Applied Physics Letters, 1 APL Materials, 2 Journal of Applied Physics, 1 AIP Advanced, 1 Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A, 1 Journal of the American Ceramic Society, and 1 Materials Horizons), one conference proceeding (Proceedings of SPIE), and one editorial perspective (Science).

For the broader impacts, this study has developed effective material strategies for achieving nonvolatile voltage-control of the electronic, magnetic, and optical properties in novel hybrid materials, which can facilitate the development of reconfigurable nanoelectronic, spintronic, and photonic applications. The ferroelectric polarization control of metal-insulator transition in strontium iridate films can be utilized to design all-oxide ferroelectric field effect transistors and tunnel junctions for low power logic and memory applications. The strong perpendicular magnetic anisotropy and robust anomalous Hall effect observed in ultrathin nickel cobaltite films make it a promising material candidate for developing magnetic tunnel junctions and sensor devices.

Two postdoctoral scholars and seven graduate students (two females) have participated in this research. One graduate student completed his Ph.D. dissertation by the end of the program. Leveraging this funding, the research group has hosted the research activities of 4 undergraduate students (2 females with 1 minority student), one high school student (female), and one high school teacher. The PI and her group members have actively outreached to K-12 students and the general public by participating in activities such as the Nebraska Nanodays, the NCMN/Bright Lights NanoCamp, the A Universe of Stories event organized by the Lincoln City Library, the Science Night Live event organized by Nebraska MRSEC, and the LPS Spark Summer Learning program Nano Week. The PI has been developing a physics comic series as an effective tool to motivate female students to engage in physics learning at an early age. One comic episode based on Newton's Third Law has been created, which is hosted on the research group's website.
